doc.field: SPD Parliamentary Group Approves Budget Cuts

The Executive Committee of the SPD Parliamentary Group approved the government's proposal in a closed-door meeting in Potsdam. Parliamentary Party Leader Struck said there was no alternative to the budget rehabilitation bill. Gerhard Schroeder had apparently been able push it through for now. The Chancellor personally attended the meeting today. A group of about 40 dissidents from within the parliamentary group had threatened to vote against the bill if socially just changes were not made. A reintroduction of the capital gains tax was absolutely out of the question for the Chancellor. The issue of de-linking the development of net salaries and pensions should also not be revisited. The vote in the Bundestag is scheduled for October 29.
Hoeppner in Favor of Reintroducing Capital Gains Tax

Saxony-Anhalt's State Premier Hoeppner announced an initiative to reintroduce the capital gains tax. Hoeppner said in Magdeburg that he plans to seek supporters so that the initiative has a chance to win a majority in the Bundesrat or upper house of Parliament.
Doctors Plan National Campaign against Health Care Reform

The associations for physicians, hospitals and health care practitioners are gearing up for an attack against the planned health care reform. The so-called "Health Alliance 2000" announced a national campaign today to mobilize the population against the reform. According to the physicians, it is a fundamental mistake that the reform is driven by economic criteria and the medical considerations are ignored.
Dressler Calls for Persistence with Health Care Reform

The SPD Deputy Parliamentary Party Leader Dressler called on the governing coalition not to give in during the debate on health care reform. The SPD's healthcare expert said in a newspaper interview that the only thing that was important to those in the "Health Alliance 2000" was their own income. Dressler called on the coalition to stay steadfast in order to avoid a cost explosion and increases in premiums.
Mass Grave Discovered in Kosovo's German Sector

Another mass grave with approximately 50 bodies was discovered in Kosovo. According to a statement by British Foreign Minister Cook, the international police squad found the bodies beneath a garbage dump in the town of Ljubizda. The mass grave is located in the German sector. Federal Defense Minister Scharping visited soldiers stationed in Kosovo this afternoon.
Telekom Plans Bonus Point System

The German telephone company Telekom is planning to introduce a premium scheme to reward faithful customers. A spokesperson for Telekom said that the concept consisted of bonus points for telephone usage. Points would also be awarded for cellular phone calls and internet usage over the Telekom network. The bonus points would then be redeemed for a credit on the customer's phone bill or for other articles.
Third Trial of Monika Boettcher

The third trial against Monika Boettcher, formerly Monika Weimar, began today before the Regional Court in Frankfurt am Main. The 41-year-old woman is being tried again for allegedly murdering her 5- and 7-year-old daughters 13 years ago. She has consistently denied the allegations, claiming her husband did it. In the center of this trial is Monika Boettcher's own testimony. Many more details of the story are being heard than in the trial in Giessen in which she refused to testify.
Another Guilty Verdict in Reemtsmar Kidnapping Trial

Three years after the kidnapping of Jan-Phillip Reemtsmar, heir to millions, a third perpetrator has been sentenced to 6 years imprisonment. The Regional Court in Hamburg convicted Laskowski, a 33-year-old Polish man, of hostage-taking and being an accessory to kidnapping and ransoming.
Four Children Killed in Apartment Fire

Four children, aged between 2 and 9 years old, died this morning in a fire in an apartment house in Ludwigshafen. The parents were hospitalized for smoke inhalation and severe shock. The cause of the fire has not yet been determined.
Investigation into Free Tickets for Stuttgart Officials

The Public Prosecutor's Office in Stuttgart is investigating favoritism allegations against 300 officials and state politicians. They allegedly received free tickets for busses and trains from the Transit Authority. The Stuttgarter Strassenbahn-AG, as a member company of the Transit Authority, said that giving tickets away to officials and politicians had been the custom for many years. Nevertheless, the mayor of Stuttgart Schuster, four district presidents as well as other officials are under investigation on the charge of favoritism.
Tennis: Kiefer Makes Third Round of US Open
At the US Open Tennis Championships in New York, Nicola Kiefer has reached the third round. He prevailed in the German duel 6:3, 6:2 and 6:2 against qualifier Michael Kohlmann.
